tema1.question: What is the purpose of the OSI model in networking?

answers.answer: To define an architecture for network protocols.
To establish a framework for software development.
To specify the physical network infrastructure.

tema1.question: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for end-to-end communication and provides services like encryption and decryption?
What is the primary function of the Network Layer in the OSI model?
What layer does the ARP protocol operate in and what is its main purpose?

answers.answer: Layer-1, map IP addresses to MAC addresses.
Layer-3, resolve domain names to IP addresses.

tema1.question: Which layer does a router operate in, and what is its main function?

answers.answer: Layer-2, connects devices within the same network.
Layer-2, forwards packets between different networks.
Layer-3, connects devices within the same network.
Layer-3, forwards packets between different networks.

tema1.question: What layer does the ICMP protocol operate in, and what is the purpose of the protocol?
Which of the following is only a layer-2 device in an Ethernet-based computer network?
What is the purpose of DHCP protocol in a LAN (Local Area Network)?

answers.answer: To dynamically manage assignment of layer-2 addresses (MAC) to hosts.
To dynamically manage assignment of layer-3 addresses (IP) to hosts.
To dynamically manage assignment of layer-4 addresses (ports) to hosts.

tema1.question: Which protocol in the TCP/IP stack is responsible for ensuring that data packets are delivered reliably and in order?
What layer in the TCP/IP model does the UDP protocol operate in and what is its main purpose?
Which of the following protocols belong to the Internet layer in the TCP/IP model?
When used for computer communications, what is the main benefit of packet switched networks?

answers.answer: It does not require a call setup phase prior to data transmission.
It provides a dedicated physical path for data transmission.
It ensures that packets always arrive in the order they are transmitted.

tema1.question: When considering computer networks, a protocol defines:

answers.answer: The message types and the message format that devices exchange.
Only the message types that devices exchange.
Only the message format that devices exchange.

tema1.question: What is the main organization that standardizes Internet protocols in RFC (Request for Comments) documents?
In the TCP/IP model, what is the name of the data unit exchanged by hosts at the transport layer?
In an IP network, what does the RTT (Round-Trip Time) measure?

answers.answer: The time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination, including the transmission, propagation and queueing times.
The time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination and for the acknowledgement to return back, including the transmission, propagation and queueing times.
The time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination, including the time to setup the circuit, the time to transmit the data, and the time to tear-down the circuit.

tema1.question: In an IPv4 network, what is the length (i.e., number of bits) of the network mask of a Class B address?

In an IPv4 network, in addition to the host address (i.e., 147.83.77.12), what other information has to be configured at the network layer to be able to send packets to another host from a different network (i.e., 8.8.8.8.)?

answers.answer: The network mask and the gateway address.
The network address, the gateway address and the address of the DNS server.
The address of the DHCP server.

tema1.question: What of the following IPv4 subnets is used by ISPs (Internet Service Providers) to offer the CG-NAT service?
What field in the IPv4 header is used to identify the transport layer protocol that is being carried by the packet (i.e., TCP, UDP or ICMP)?
What of the following services is provided by UDP (User Datagram Protocol) at the transport layer?
At the transport layer, what protocol and port number does the DNS service use?
At the transport layer, what is the length of the source and destination port which allow to multiplex the applications running on the same host?
At the transport layer, what is the total length of the UDP header?
Which of the following network protocols does NOT use TCP for reliable delivery of data?
When establishing a connection with a remote host, TCP uses the 3-way handshake mechanism. What bits of the TCP header are used by the sender (S) and the receiver (R) during the 3-way handshake?

answers.answer: S: SYN, R: ACK, S: ACK.
S: SYN, R: SYN+ACK, S: ACK.
S: SYN, R: SYN, S: FIN.
S: SYN, R: SYN+ACK, S: ACK.

tema1.question: During the slow start phase of the credit-based flow control mechanism, TCP x the y every z.

answers.answer: x = doubles, y = congestion window, z = RTT.
x = increments by one unit, y = packet buffer, z = second.
x = increments by one unit, y = congestion window, z = RTT.
x = doubles, y = congestion window, z = second.

tema1.question: The original Ethernet standard, developed in 1972 at Xerox PARC for Local Area Networks (LANs), provided a data transfer speed of x Mbps over a y cable using a z topology.

In an Ethernet network, what is the equipment that isolates the collision domain in each physical port, effectively creating a star topology and ensuring that transmissions from different stations cannot collide?
In an Ethernet network, what is the length of the MAC address?

A host has a MAC address (ab:cd:ef:12:34:56), as well as an IPv4 address (192.168.100.10/24) and a gateway address (192.168.100.1) configured. If the host executes ’ping 8.8.8.8’, what will be the target protocol (IP) and target hardware (MAC) addresses of the ARP Request message (i.e., not the Ethernet frame)? Assume the ARP table is initially empty.
A router receives an IP packet with TTL=1. What is the type and code of the ICMP message that the router will send back to the packet source?

answers.answer: The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=0 and Code=0 (Echo reply).
The router will send an ICJMP packet of Type=3 and Code=3 (Destination unreachable).
The router will forward the IP packet to the destination without sending an ICMP packet.

tema1.question: If a router fails to resolve the data-link layer address of a target host using the ARP protocol to deliver a frame (i.e., direct deliver), what ICMP message does it send back to the origin?

answers.answer: The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=0 and Code=0 (Echo reply).
The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=5 and Code=0 (Redirect).
The router will send an ICMP packet of Type=11 and Code=0 (Time exceeded).

tema1.question: In IPv4 networks, what protocol is used to automatically configure the host address, network mask, gateway address and DNS servers address, as well as other configuration parameters?
What layer of the TCP/IP model does the DHCP protocol operate in? What protocol and source port does the DHCP client use to send packets to the server?

A host has the 01:02:03:04:05:06 MAC address and the DHCP server has the 0a:0b:0c:0d:0e:0f MAC address. In the DHCP allocation process, what is the destination MAC address of the Ethernet header that the host and the server use to send packets?

A host sends a DHCP Discover request to acquire the network address and mask from a DHCP server with MAC address 01:02:03:04:05:06 and IP address 192.168.100.254. What is the destination address of the packet at the data-link layer (i.e., MAC address) and the network layer (i.e., IP address) that the host sends the packet to?
If a LAN (Local Area Network) has two DHCP servers operating at the same time, what field of the DHCP packet header is used to distinguish to which server is a client talking to?
When a host requests an IP address using DHCP, what is the message that it sends back to the DHCP server to confirm the address that the DHCP server has offered?
In addition to the IP address, what other information is provided by the DHCP server to ensure that the host can execute the ’ping google.com’ command and get a response?

answers.answer: Only the network mask and the DNS servers.
Only the network gateway and the network mask.
Only the network gateway and the DNS servers.

tema1.question: Your computer has the following EUI-48 address: 1a:2b:3c:4d:5e:6f. If you are given the following IPv6 prefix 2000:abc::/32 in the dead subnet, what is the link-local address of your host?
Your AS is assigned the IPv6 network prefix 2000:abc:def::/56. How many subnetworks (i.e., sites) can you have? How many hosts can each subnetwork have?
In an IPv6 network, which protocol is used to match the IPv6 address and the physical address (i.e., MAC address) of a host to enable delivering frames locally?
Which of the following fields have been removed in the IPv6 header when compared to the IPv4 header? Do not consider IPv6 header extensions.
The size of an IPv6 address is:
You are given the following IPv6 address: 2001:0000:8489:0000:0000:0AAB:0038:0001. Which of the following is the correct short representation of the IPv6 address?
What are the two parts that form a global unique IPv6 address?
What prefix is used for IPv6 multicast addresses?
What is the IPv6 multicast address of All-nodes in link-local scope?
Which of the following IPv6 network prefixes is used to send packets over a local network?

tema2.question: What is the international organization that is responsible for assigning Internet resources (i.e., AS numbers and IP address ranges) world-wide?
What routing protocol is used to interconnect Autonomous Systems (AS) on the Internet? What transport layer protocol and port does it use?

A company wishes to announce its own IP network prefix to the Internet using various service providers. What kind of IP address prefix does it have to request to the RIR? What connectivity model would it be best to ensure connectivity in case one of the service providers fail?
What is the RIR in charge of providing Internet resources in North America?
In a router, what plane is responsible to fill in the routing table based on the information provided by the network administrator or neighbour routers using routing protocols?
What is the algorithm executed in the router forwarding plane to determine which interface a packet has to be forwarded to based on its destination IP address?

In a router, for each destination network, which is the table that contains the addresses of the next hop (i.e., the address of the router to which the packets have to be forwarded to) and the exit interface of the packet?

For the same destination network, which of the following mechanisms to fill in the routing table has the smallest administrative distance and, thus, is preferred by the router, as it provides the most reliable information?
Which of the following routing protocol families are used for routing within an Autonomous System?
Which of the following routing protocols is NOT an IGP (Interior Gateway Protocol) (although it can be used as one in certain scenarios)?

answers.answer: None, all mentioned protocols are IGPs.

tema2.question: What routing algorithm does RIP use to compute the best path between two given points in a network?
What transport layer protocol and source/destination port do RIP routers use to communicate?
What communication model do routers that execute RIPv1 use to communicate between them?
What is the main limitation of the RIP routing protocol when dealing with large networks?

answers.answer: The network diameter is limited to 15 hops.
It is prone to routing loops due to the slow convergence time.
The metric (i.e., number of hops) cannot be changed.
All the above answers are known limitations of RIP.

tema2.question: What is the main benefit of RIPv2 when compared to RIPv1?

answers.answer: It is no longer limited to a maximum number of hops (i.e., 15).
It is no longer limited by the use of classful routing (i.e., class A, B or C).
It is no longer limited by the default administrative distance (i.e., 120).
All the above answers are correct.

tema2.question: The RIPv2 protocol supports neighbor authentication by:

answers.answer: Setting the AFI field in the header to 0xFFFF.
Setting the Command field in the header to 0xFFFF.
Setting the Unused field in the header to 0xFFFF.

tema2.question: Which of the protection mechanisms introduced in RIPv2 to reduce convergence time and the chance of routing loops is based on the principle ’Not advertising routes through the same interface from which the router has learned them’?
With respect to RIPv1, that only supports classful routing, which field is added in the RIPv2 protocol header to support VLSM and CIDR?
Which RIP timer is used by the router to determine when to send routing updates to neighbor routers?
OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) is an x routing protocol based on the principle of y routing using the z routing algorithm.
What transport layer protocol does OSPF use to communicate neighbor routers?

answers.answer: OSPF uses UDP as the transport layer protocol.
OSPF uses TCP as the transport layer protocol.
OSPF uses ICMP as the transport layer protocol.
None, OSPF is transported directly over IP using protocol 89.

tema2.question: If a router learns two routes to the same destination network (i.e., 147.83.0.0/16), one via RIP and the other via OSPF, which one will become active in the routing table and will be used to forward packets?

answers.answer: The router learned via RIP, as it has a higher administrative distance (120).
The router learned via OSPF, as it has a smaller administrative distance (110).
The router learned via RIP, since it has a smaller administrative distance (110).
Both routes will become active, since the administrative distance is not used for such purpose.

tema2.question: The metric that OSPF uses to determine which path between two networks is better than the other is based on...

answers.answer: ...the delay of the slowest link in the path between both networks.
...the bandwidth of the fastest link in the path between both networks.
...the number of hops (i.e., routers) in the path between both networks, as it is done in RIP.
...a combination of the number of hops and the cost of each link in the path between both networks.

tema2.question: An OSPF router has a RouterID = 1.1.1.1 that is unique. In which state is the OSPF state machine when a HELLO message is received from a neighbor router that contains the same RouterID (i.e., 1.1.1.1)?
OSPF operates in a broadcast network (i.e., Ethernet) with 6 routers. Thanks to selecting a DR and a BDR router, how many adjacencies will these routers form?
In OSPF, which packet type is used by routers to send the missing content of the LSDB to neighbor routers?
Which is of the following is a benefit of using OSPF with respect to RIP?

answers.answer: It converges faster and better avoids creating routing loops since all routers have a complete view of the network topology.
It no longer requires periodic updates between routers, only triggered updates upon topology changes (i.e. link or router failure).
It is no longer limited by the maximum number of hops since all routers have a complete view of the network topology.
All the above answers are benefits of OSPF with respect RIP.

tema2.question: Which routing protocol is used for routing between ASs? What is the routing principle that it is based upon?
What is the metric that BGP uses to determine which is best path between two AS on the Internet?
The BGP state machine has 6 states. In which state does BGP send an OPEN message and waits for the response of its peer?

When the connection between two BGP peers is established, which kind of message types do routers exchange to add new routes (i.e., advertise) or remove (i.e., withdraw) routers that are no longer available?
What are the BGP attributes that all routers have to support, are always present, and are propagated globally?
Which of the following BGP attributes is NOT a well-known and mandatory?
Which of the following BGP attributes is a well-known and mandatory attribute, and includes the sequence of ASNs a network prefix is propagated through?
What field in the BGP open message header indicates how long a neighbor router can keep the BGP session open without receiving messages from its neighbor?
What kind of BGP attribute is the MED?

Which mechanism based on public-key infrastructure has been implemented on Internet routers to validate the origin of the BGP announcements (i.e., AS number and IP network prefixes) and reduce the chances of prefix leaks and hijacking?

A router has the following entries in its routing table. If the router receives an IP packet with destination address 185.133.89.100, to which next-hop address and interface will it forward the packet to? Despite not being shown for simplicity, assume that the next-hop addresses and interfaces can be resolved by the router.

A router has the following entries in its routing table. If the router receives an IP packet with destination address 185.132.89.144, to which next-hop address and interface will it forward the packet to? Despite not being shown for simplicity, assume that the next-hop addresses and interfaces can be resolved by the router.

A router has the following entries in its routing table. If the router receives an IP packet with destination address 185.132.89.120, to which next-hop address and interface will it forward the packet to? Despite not being shown for simplicity, assume that the next-hop addresses and interfaces can be resolved by the router.
